stem: A 16-year-old client presents to the surgical center for an elective appendectomy. Based on the documentation in the Legal Status & Consent Verification tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition/status, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: 16-year-old male presenting for surgery. Parents are not present.
Background: Client states he lives in his own apartment and has been self-supporting for 6 months. He states, 'I am legally emancipated by the court.'
Assessment: Client is alert, oriented, and able to describe the surgical procedure in his own words.
Recommendation: Verify legal status before proceeding with signatures.

tabs.title: Legal Status & Consent Verification
tabs.content:
Document TypeStatusNotes
Birth CertificateVerifiedAge: 16 years
Court DecreeAttachedDecree of Emancipation (Certified)
Insurance CardPrimary HolderSelf-insured

actionOptions.text: Verify the certified court decree of emancipation
Delay surgery until a legal guardian arrives at the facility
Witness the client's signature on the surgical consent form
Obtain a telephone order for emergency life-saving surgery

parameterOptions.text: Client's verbalized understanding of risks and benefits
Presence of a biological parent in the recovery room
Provider's notification of the client's legal status

rationale.correct: The client has a certified Court Decree of Emancipation (Condition: c1). This status allows the minor to consent for their own medical treatment. The nurse must verify the documentation (a1) and can then proceed to witness the client's own signature (a3). The nurse should ensure the minor understands the procedure (p1) and that the surgical team/provider is aware of the legal status change (p3).
clinicalPearls: Emancipated minors are legally considered adults for medical decision-making.
Common triggers for emancipation: Marriage, Military service, or Court order.
The nurse's role in consent is ONLY to witness the signature and verify the patient is competent; the SURGEON is responsible for explaining the risks/benefits.

questionTrap.trap: Requiring a parent even for an emancipated minor.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: If the court has granted emancipation, the parents no longer have legal authority. Treating the minor as an adult is the correct legal path.

mnemonic.title: M-M-C
mnemonic.expansion: Minor can consent if: Married, Military, or Court-ordered (Emancipated).
